response_dict_list.question: When does the most dramatic growth happen for a startup?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: When the startup only has three or four people.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: The most dramatic growth for a startup happens when it only has three or four people.
retrieved_context: The really dramatic growth happens when a startup only has three or four people, so only three or four people see that, whereas tens of thousands see business as it's practiced by Boeing or Philip Morris.

Learning from Founders

January 2007

But while it is very common for startups to die from running through their initial funding and then being unable to raise more, the underlying cause is usually slow growth or excessive spending rather than insufficient effort to extract money from existing customers.

response_dict_list.question: What is the problem with business culture versus start up culture with respect to productivity?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: In business culture, energy is expended on outward appearance to the detriment of productivity, while in startup culture there is no value of appearance it's all about productivity.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: The problem with business culture versus start-up culture with respect to productivity is that conventional ideas of professionalism, such as dressing in suits, sitting in conference rooms, and producing thick reports, are ingrained in our minds. This focus on appearances and looking productive actually hinders productivity in organizations. Start-ups, on the other hand, prioritize performance and have a more dynamic and flexible approach to work. They are able to generate dramatic growth and come up with innovative ideas because they are not bound by traditional business practices. The disconnect lies in the fact that start-ups, despite being the most productive part of the economy, are often overlooked or misunderstood by larger organizations. The energy spent on appearing impressive in traditional business culture often detracts from actual performance, whereas start-ups focus on driving real results.
retrieved_context: )Ditto for most of the other differences between startups and what passes for productivity in big companies.And yet conventional ideas of professionalism have such an iron grip on our minds that even startup founders are affected by them.In our startup, when outsiders came to visit we tried hard to seem "professional."

If you looked in people's heads (or stock photo collections) for images representing "business," you'd get images of people dressed up in suits, groups sitting around conference tables looking serious, Powerpoint presentations, people producing thick reports for one another to read.Early stage startups are the exact opposite of this.

Of course, big companies won't be able to do everything these startups do.In big companies there's always going to be more politics, and less scope for individual decisions.But seeing what startups are really like will at least show other organizations what to aim for.

Business is broken the same way that car was.The effort that goes into looking productive is not merely wasted, but actually makes organizations less productive.Suits, for example.Suits do not help people to think better.

The really dramatic growth happens when a startup only has three or four people, so only three or four people see that, whereas tens of thousands see business as it's practiced by Boeing or Philip Morris.

And yet they're probably the most productive part of the whole economy.Why the disconnect?I think there's a general principle at work here: the less energy people expend on performance, the more they expend on appearances to compensate.More often than not the energy they expend on seeming impressive makes their actual performance worse.

But while it is very common for startups to die from running through their initial funding and then being unable to raise more, the underlying cause is usually slow growth or excessive spending rather than insufficient effort to extract money from existing customers.

The earliest phase is usually the most productive.That's when they have the really big ideas.Imagine what Apple was like when 100% of its employees were either Steve Jobs or Steve Wozniak.The striking thing about this phase is that it's completely different from most people's idea of what business is like.

response_dict_list.question: What's the single biggest thing the government could do to increase the number of startups in this country?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: Establish a new class of visa for startup founders.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: The single biggest thing the government could do to increase the number of startups in this country is to establish a new class of visa for startup founders. This would allow the government to leverage the expertise and investment of recognized startup investors as a test of whether a company is a real startup. By allowing more startup founders into the country, it would create more jobs for Americans and have a visible effect on the economy.
retrieved_context: The single biggest thing the government could do to increase the number of startups in this country is a policy that would cost nothing: establish a new class of visa for startup founders.

The government could not do better than to piggyback on their expertise, and use investment by recognized startup investors as the test of whether a company was a real startup.How would the government decide who's a startup investor?The same way they decide what counts as a university for student visas.

The biggest constraint on the number of new startups that get created in the US is not tax policy or employment law or even Sarbanes-Oxley.It's that we won't let the people who want to start them into the country.

In fact they'd cause there to be more jobs for Americans, because the companies they started would hire more employees as they grew.The tricky part might seem to be how one defined a startup.But that could be solved quite easily: let the market decide.Startup investors work hard to find the best startups.

Letting just 10,000 startup founders into the country each year could have a visible effect on the economy.If we assume 4 people per startup, which is probably an overestimate, that's 2500 new companies.Each year.

We'll establish our own accreditation procedure.We know who one another are.10,000 people is a drop in the bucket by immigration standards, but would represent a huge increase in the pool of startup founders.

"PB made a point in a talk once that I now mention to every startup we fund: that it's better, initially, to make a small number of users really love you than a large number kind of like you.If I could tell startups only ten sentences, this would be one of them.

They wouldn't all grow as big as Google, but out of 2500 some would come close.By definition these 10,000 founders wouldn't be taking jobs from Americans: it could be part of the terms of the visa that they couldn't work for existing companies, only new ones they'd founded.

response_dict_list.question: How could one create a rigorous government definition of what a startup is to categorize whether a business is a startup?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: One could define a startup as a company that has received investment by recognized startup investors. An accreditation procedure would be determined to establish recognized startup investors.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: The government could create a rigorous definition of what a startup is by allowing the market to decide. This means that the government could rely on recognized startup investors to determine whether a company qualifies as a startup. By using investment by these investors as a test, the government can ensure that only genuine startups are categorized as such. This approach would leverage the expertise of startup investors who work hard to find the best startups, and it would also align with the idea of letting the market determine what constitutes a startup.

response_dict_list.question: Why is frienship a good quality of founders?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: Friendship is a good quality of founders because building a startup is tough and without a strong friendship building the startup will tear the founders apart.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: Friendship is a good quality of founders because it helps to establish a strong and positive relationship between the founders. When founders genuinely like and work well together, it creates a solid foundation for the startup. This strong bond allows them to effectively collaborate, communicate, and make decisions together, which is crucial for the success of the company. Additionally, friendship among founders can contribute to a positive and supportive work environment, fostering creativity, motivation, and loyalty.

Why It's Safe for Founders to Be Nice

August 2015

I recently got an email from a founder that helped me understand something important: why it's safe for startup founders to be nice people.

What drives the most successful founders is the same thing that drives most people who make things: the company is their project.[2] In fact since 2 ≈ 1.05 ^ 15, the un-rapacious founder is always 15 weeks behind the rapacious one.

In print they had to cut the last item because they didn't have room.)1.DeterminationThis has turned out to be the most important quality in startup founders.We thought when we started Y Combinator that the most important quality would be intelligence.That's the myth in the Valley.

What makes startups different is that usually it doesn't.Startups usually win by making something so great that people recommend it to their friends.And being rapacious not only doesn't help you do that, but probably hurts.
If they know they can't fire the founders, they'll have to choose founders they can trust.And that's who they should have been choosing all along.

response_dict_list.question: Why is determination the most important quality in startup founders?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: Because when building a startup you're going to hit a lot of obstacles, and determination will prevent one from getting demoralized by the constant obstacles.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: Determination is the most important quality in startup founders because they are likely to encounter numerous obstacles and setbacks along the way. It is crucial for founders to have the resilience and perseverance to overcome these challenges without getting easily demoralized. Additionally, determination is what drives successful founders to make their company their project and continuously work towards achieving their goals.
retrieved_context: In print they had to cut the last item because they didn't have room.)1.DeterminationThis has turned out to be the most important quality in startup founders.We thought when we started Y Combinator that the most important quality would be intelligence.That's the myth in the Valley.

And certainly you don't want founders to be stupid.But as long as you're over a certain threshold of intelligence, what matters most is determination.You're going to hit a lot of obstacles.You can't be the sort of person who gets demoralized easily.

What drives the most successful founders is the same thing that drives most people who make things: the company is their project.[2] In fact since 2 ≈ 1.05 ^ 15, the un-rapacious founder is always 15 weeks behind the rapacious one.

FriendshipEmpirically it seems to be hard to start a startup with just one founder.Most of the big successes have two or three.And the relationship between the founders has to be strong.They must genuinely like one another, and work well together.

And the startups where they have to resort to compulsion are not the ones that matter anyway.VCs make most of their money from a few big hits, and those aren't them.Knowing that founders will keep control of the board may even help VCs pick better.

The world of startups is so unpredictable that you need to be able to modify your dreams on the fly.The best metaphor I've found for the combination of determination and flexibility you need is a running back.

As I've written before, one of the things that has surprised me most about startups is how few of the most successful founders are like that.Maybe successful people in other industries are; I don't know; but not startup founders.

response_dict_list.question: For startups, what does board control mean in practice?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: During board meetings, matters are decided in the discussion preceding the vote, not in the vote itself, which is usually unanimous. If opinion is divided in such discussions, the side that knows it would lose in a vote tends to be less insistent. This is what board control means in practice.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: Board control for startups means that the founders of the company retain majority control of the board seats even after a series A round of funding. This means that the founders have the power to make decisions and have the final say in matters that are discussed during board meetings. While investors may have certain veto powers over big decisions, the founders still have the ultimate control and influence over the direction and decisions of the company. Board control is not just about outvoting others in board meetings, but also about having the ability to shape the discussions and decisions that take place before any voting occurs.
retrieved_context: So while board control is not total control, it's not imaginary either.There's inevitably a difference in how things feel within the company.Which means if it becomes the norm for founders to retain board control after a series A, that will change the way things feel in the whole startup world.

Founder Control

December 2010

Want to start a startup?Get funded by Y Combinator.Someone we funded is talking to VCs now, and asked me how common it was for a startup's founders to retain control of the board after a series A round.

And the startups where they have to resort to compulsion are not the ones that matter anyway.VCs make most of their money from a few big hits, and those aren't them.Knowing that founders will keep control of the board may even help VCs pick better.

In a dozen companies we've funded, the founders still had a majority of the board seats after the series A round.I feel like we're at a tipping point here.A lot of VCs still act as if founders retaining board control after a series A is unheard-of.

A lot of them don't care that much personally about whether founders keep board control.They just don't want to seem like they had to make concessions.Which means if letting the founders keep control stops being perceived as a concession, it will rapidly become much more common.

Control of a company is a more complicated matter than simply outvoting other parties in board meetings.Investors usually get vetos over certain big decisions, like selling the company, regardless of how many board seats they have.And board votes are rarely split.

Matters are decided in the discussion preceding the vote, not in the vote itself, which is usually unanimous.But if opinion is divided in such discussions, the side that knows it would lose in a vote will tend to be less insistent.That's what board control means in practice.

He said VCs told him this almost never happened.Ten years ago that was true.In the past, founders rarely kept control of the board through a series A.The traditional series A board consisted of two founders, two VCs, and one independent member.

response_dict_list.question: What's in the way of founders keeping board control after a series A?
response_dict_list.reference_answer: The perception that founders keeping board control after a series A being a concession a VC has made when negotiating with startups. VCs do not want to look like they've lost a negotiation. If founders keeping control after a series A is the norm, then it happening will not look like the VCs lost the negotiation.
response_dict_list.llm_answer: The perception that founders retaining board control after a series A is uncommon is one of the main obstacles. Many VCs do not want to appear as if they had to make concessions. However, if letting founders keep control stops being seen as a concession, it is likely to become more common. Additionally, some VCs may prefer to fund founders who are more experienced and have a strong desire for control, like Mark Zuckerberg. Ultimately, the startups where VCs have to resort to forcing founders to give up board control may not be the ones that have the potential for significant success.
retrieved_context: In a dozen companies we've funded, the founders still had a majority of the board seats after the series A round.I feel like we're at a tipping point here.A lot of VCs still act as if founders retaining board control after a series A is unheard-of.

So while board control is not total control, it's not imaginary either.There's inevitably a difference in how things feel within the company.Which means if it becomes the norm for founders to retain board control after a series A, that will change the way things feel in the whole startup world.

Founder Control

December 2010

Want to start a startup?Get funded by Y Combinator.Someone we funded is talking to VCs now, and asked me how common it was for a startup's founders to retain control of the board after a series A round.

He said VCs told him this almost never happened.Ten years ago that was true.In the past, founders rarely kept control of the board through a series A.The traditional series A board consisted of two founders, two VCs, and one independent member.

A lot of them don't care that much personally about whether founders keep board control.They just don't want to seem like they had to make concessions.Which means if letting the founders keep control stops being perceived as a concession, it will rapidly become much more common.

Or if they are, they are, like Mark Zuckerberg, the kind of noobs and control freaks VCs should be trying to fund more of.Founders retaining control after a series A is clearly heard-of.And barring financial catastrophe, I think in the coming year it will become the norm.

More recently the recipe is often one founder, one VC, and one independent.In either case the founders lose their majority.But not always.Mark Zuckerberg kept control of Facebook's board through the series A and still has it today.Mark Pincus has kept control of Zynga's too.

And the startups where they have to resort to compulsion are not the ones that matter anyway.VCs make most of their money from a few big hits, and those aren't them.Knowing that founders will keep control of the board may even help VCs pick better.
